required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Efficacy and Safety of Oxycodone/Naloxone Controlled-release Tablets (OXN) Compared to Placebo in Opioid-experienced Subjects With Moderate to Severe Chronic Low Back Pain
clinical_study.official_title: A Randomized, Double-blind, Placebo-controlled, Multicenter Trial With an Enriched Study Design to Assess the Efficacy and Safety of Oxycodone/Naloxone Controlled-release Tablets (OXN) Compared to Placebo in Opioid-experienced Subjects With Moderate to Severe Pain Due to Chronic Low Back Pain Who Require Around-the-clock Opioid Therapy

brief_summary.textblock: The primary objective of this study is to assess the efficacy and safety of OXN compared to placebo in opioid-experienced subjects with moderate to severe pain due to chronic low back pain who require around-the-clock opioid therapy.

primary_outcome.measure: The "Average Pain Over the Last 24 Hours" at Week 12 of the Double-blind Period
primary_outcome.description: The "average pain over the last 24 hours" score was collected using an 11-point numerical rating scale ranging from 0 to 10; where 0=no pain and 10=pain as bad as you can imagine.

secondary_outcome.measure: The Sleep Disturbance Subscale of the MOS Sleep Scale at Weeks 4, 8, and 12
secondary_outcome.description: The scale consists of 12 individual items (4 sleep disturbance, 2 sleep adequacy, 1 quantity of sleep, 3 somnolence, 1 snoring, 1 shortness of breath). Only Sleep Disturbance Subscale questions 1, 3, 7, and 8 were analyzed; scores range from 0 to 100, where higher scores indicate greater sleep disturbance.

The PGIC observational scale was completed by the subject. Subjects were asked to assess the change in overall status relative to the start of the study. The scale has only 1 item, which measures global change of overall status by the subject on a 7-point scale (Very much improved, Much improved, Minimally improved, No change, Minimally worse, Much worse, Very much worse), where 1 = very much improved and 7 = very much worse. The proportion of subjects responding "much improved" and "very much improved" was summarized by treatment group and compared between groups using an exact test.

other_outcome.measure: Responder Analysis for Subjects With a ≥ 30% Reduction in Pain Compared to Baseline
other_outcome.description: A subject's response to treatment was defined as the percentage reduction from the screening mean pain score to the "average pain over the last 24 hours" score for week 12 of the double-blind period.

other_outcome.measure: Responder Analysis for Subjects With a ≥ 50% Reduction in Pain Compared to Baseline
other_outcome.description: A subject's response to treatment was defined as the percentage reduction from the screening mean pain score to the "average pain over the last 24 hours" score for week 12 of the double-blind period.

intervention.description: Oxycodone/Naloxone Controlled-release tablets (10/5 mg, 20/10 mg, 30/15 mg, 40/20 mg) taken orally every 12 hours
Placebo tablets to match OXN taken orally every 12 hours

clinical_study.keyword: Moderate to severe chronic low back pain

participant_flow.recruitment_details: First subject first visit: 25-May-2011; Last subject last visit: 15-Oct-2012. The study was conducted at 132 medical/research sites in the United States.
participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: Opioid-experienced subjects with moderate to severe pain due to chronic low back pain, who required around-the-clock opioid therapy.

group.title: Open-label Titration OXN
group.description: The open-label titration was designed to identify a stable, effective, and tolerable dose of OXN for each subject.

group.title: OXN Group
group.description: Oxycodone/Naloxone Controlled-release Tablets (OXN) Oxycodone/Naloxone Controlled-release: Oxycodone/Naloxone Controlled-release tablets (10/5 mg, 20/10 mg, 30/15 mg, 40/20 mg) taken orally every 12 hours

group.title: Placebo Group
group.description: Placebo tablets to match OXN Placebo: Placebo tablets to match OXN taken orally every 12 hours

outcome.title: The “Average Pain Over the Last 24 Hours” at Week 12 of the Double-blind Period
outcome.description: The “average pain over the last 24 hours” score was collected using an 11-point numerical rating scale ranging from 0 to 10; where 0=no pain and 10=pain as bad as you can imagine.
outcome.population: The full analysis population for efficacy (N = 600) was the group of subjects who were randomized and received at least 1 dose of double-blind study drug

measure.title: The “Average Pain Over the Last 24 Hours” at Week 12 of the Double-blind Period
measure.description: The “average pain over the last 24 hours” score was collected using an 11-point numerical rating scale ranging from 0 to 10; where 0=no pain and 10=pain as bad as you can imagine.
measure.population: The full analysis population for efficacy (N = 600) was the group of subjects who were randomized and received at least 1 dose of double-blind study drug

analysis.p_value_desc: A gate-keeping strategy and a Bonferroni-Holm method was used to control the family-wise (primary and secondary efficacy analysis) error rate at the 5% level.
analysis.method_desc: Mixed-model repeated measures analysis of pain data using a pattern mixture model framework

outcome.title: The Sleep Disturbance Subscale of the MOS Sleep Scale at Weeks 4, 8, and 12
outcome.description: The scale consists of 12 individual items (4 sleep disturbance, 2 sleep adequacy, 1 quantity of sleep, 3 somnolence, 1 snoring, 1 shortness of breath). Only Sleep Disturbance Subscale questions 1, 3, 7, and 8 were analyzed; scores range from 0 to 100, where higher scores indicate greater sleep disturbance.
outcome.population: The full analysis population for efficacy (N = 600) was the group of subjects who were randomized and received at least 1 dose of double-blind study drug

Only Sleep Disturbance Subscale questions 1, 3, 7, and 8 were analyzed; scores range from 0 to 100, where higher scores indicate greater sleep disturbance.
measure.population: The full analysis population for efficacy (N = 600) was the group of subjects who were randomized and received at least 1 dose of double-blind study drug

analysis.estimate_desc: Mean difference (final values) is the treatment comparison estimated using mixed model repeated measures analysis with effect for treatment, time (weeks 4, 8, 12), treatment by time interaction, and prerandomization value. Subject is a random effect.

outcome.title: Patient Global Impression of Change (PGIC)
outcome.description: The PGIC observational scale was completed by the subject. Subjects were asked to assess the change in overall status relative to the start of the study. The scale has only 1 item, which measures global change of overall status by the subject on a 7-point scale (Very much improved, Much improved, Minimally improved, No change, Minimally worse, Much worse, Very much worse), where 1 = very much improved and 7 = very much worse. The proportion of subjects responding "much improved" and "very much improved" was summarized by treatment group and compared between groups using an exact test.
outcome.population: The full analysis population for efficacy (N = 600) was the group of subjects who were randomized and received at least 1 dose of double-blind study drug

outcome.description: A subject’s response to treatment was defined as the percentage reduction from the screening mean pain score to the “average pain over the last 24 hours” score for week 12 of the double-blind period.
outcome.population: The full analysis population for efficacy (N = 600) was the group of subjects who were randomized and received at least 1 dose of double-blind study drug

analysis.groups_desc: Proportion of subjects with a response to treatment that is ≥ 30%
analysis.method_desc: Cochran-Mantel-Haenszel test: responder as dependent variable, treatment as explanatory variable, dose at time of randomization as stratifying factor

reported_events.time_frame: Adverse events (AEs) were reported from start of study participation through the period beyond study completion.
reported_events.desc: AEs were learned of through spontaneous reports and/or subject interview, or were observed during physical examinations or other safety assessments. Ongoing AEs were followed until resolution or 30 days after last study drug dose. Serious AEs up to 30 days following the last study visit were followed until the AE or sequelae resolved or stabilized.

category.title: Neoplasms benign, malignant and unspecified (incl cysts and polyps)

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: The only disclosure restriction on the PI is that the sponsor can review results communications prior to public release and can embargo communications regarding trial results for a period that is more than 60 days but less than or equal to 180 days. The sponsor cannot require changes to the communication and cannot extend the embargo.
